mods.abstract: This picture, taken from Myrtle Point on Mt. LeConte, shares one of the most typical views of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park that has been made. It shows the ruggedness, the forest-clad features, and also the elements at play. The knife-like ridges of the Greenbrier wilderness area are seen, with Mt. Guyot, Mt. Chapman, and other peaks along the state line under the drifting clouds. When clouds hang low over the Great Smokies, with a low temperature, dazzling hoar frost will almost always form on the trees and vegetation, sometimes an inch or so thick. Hoar frost is shown here on the nearby trees

titleInfo.title: Primitive Grist, or Tub Mill, Le Conte Creek

mods.abstract: When the Great Smoky Mountains National Park was established, there were a score of Mill Creeks within the park's boundaries. The name "Mill" was applied to these streams because grist mills had been built on those streams in the pioneer days. In the foothills most of the mills used the picturesque over-shot water wheels. But, back up nearer the headwaters of the streams the mills were smaller and were powered by the home-made vertical turbines. In these, fan-like blades were carved from the same piece of wood that was used for the vertical shaft. The capacity of such mills was quite small; about a bushel, or a tub full. Hence, the name "tub" mill. Note the man carrying his "turn" of corn, just left of the tiny mills.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

mods.abstract: Rising from a base of 1292 feet above sea level to an elevation of 6593 feet is majestic Mt. LeConte, Eastern America's "tallest" mountain, and grandstand of the Great Smokies. Mt. LeConte has a range in elevation of 5301 feet, or a mile and 21 feet, in a little more than a five-mile radius. It is, therefore, the "tallest" peak--highest above its own immediate base--east of the Mississipi River. The 1292-foot elevation is at Gatlinburg, Tennessee, part of which is seen in the foreground of the picture. Gatlinburg is the location of Park headquarters. This view can be seen from the highway of the 100 mile loop, via Sevierville, Gatlinburg, Maryville, etc.

titleInfo.title: Loop-Over Bridge, Chimney Tops in top right of photo

mods.abstract: One of the most interesting and picturesque features on the spectacular Tennessee side of the Newfound Gap Highway is the Loop-Over Bridge. At this unique engineering feature -- which replaced four dangerously sharp curves -- the roadway passes under a beautiful masonry bridge, thus gaining the necessary elevation for the continued gentle climb up the mountain. The Chimney Tops are seen in the background.

mods.abstract: Porters Creek heading near the Tenn-N.C. state line finds its way through Porters Flats to the middle prong of the Little Pigeon in Greenbriar Cove. While the other areas of the Great Smokies can justly lay claim to the largest single tree in the Smokies, Porters Flats lying between Greenbriar Cove and the State Line range, certainly has a claim on having the largest abundance of large trees. Photograph includes copyright statement "Thompson Co."

mods.abstract: Newfound Gap, elevation 5045 feet, is where the road of the same name crosses the main chain of the Great Smokies. There is ample room for parking hundreds of cars in this high gap. At the right is seen the starting point of the impressive Skyway, highly scenic park road, that swings gracefully near the crest of the mountain and climbs gently to an elevation of 6311 feet, near the top of 6642 foot Clingmans Dome -- highest peak in the park. A glimpse of this peak is seen in the left background.

mods.abstract: Pioneer cabins located throughout the foot-hill section of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park add a picturesque interest to the park. While many of the cabins are still occupied -- the owners having exercised their privilege to retain a life-time lease when selling their land and homes to the park -- poorer types that have been vacated have been removed so the surroundings can soon become "natural" again. Some of the better examples of mountain architecture, however, are being restored and will be preserved as a part of the park museum projects.

mods.abstract: The Loop-Over, seen here from the Chimney Tops, is one of the most unique features on the thrillling Tennessee side of the Newfound Gap Highway. Here the road makes one complete circle instead of four sharp extremely dangerous curves that were on the old road at this point. M. Le Conte is seen in the background of this picture. The small peak with the wisp of cloud is sometimes called "West-Point" and the next broader peak is "Cliff-Top". The next ones in order are "High-Top", the highest point and "Myrtle-Point", the grandstand of the Smokies.

titleInfo.title: Dome Falls on Roaring Fork Creek

mods.abstract: This is the upper of the twelve waterfalls on the tumbling Roarin' Fork, on the north side of Mt. Le Conte. A veil of cloud settled over the cascade when the picture was made, giving it a soft and attractive effect. The dome-shaped cascade also presents a spectacular appearance when the water turns to sparkling icicles, as often happens during the winter season.

mods.abstract: Most of the streams in the Great Smokies are entirely safe for drinking purposes. The water flows from deep-shaded mountain sides, free from human contamination, and it is well aerated as it dashes wildly down the steep mountain sides. Even during the hottest days of summer, the water is so cold that it will cause one's hands to ache if held in the water for a few minutes.

mods.abstract: Abrams Falls, on Abrams Creek, is in the western part of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park, three miles down the creek from Cades Cove. The Falls are reached by a trail that starts at Oliver's in the Cove, and follows approximately along Abrams Creek. Another approach is to follow the old Cooper Road, which leaves the Cove just north of Oliver's, for some three miles or to the radio aerial, then turn abruptly left and follow the trail about a mile and a half to the falls. The pool at the bottom of Abrams Falls provides the best swimming in or near the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Expert divers are unable to reach bottom just below the falls. The pool then tapers up gradually until it is from ankle-deep to knee-deep at the lower edge.

mods.abstract: The Chimney Tops from the West prong Pigeon River

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

mods.abstract: There are few, if any, more thrilling climbs in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park than the short but extremely rough ascent of the Chimney Tops, seen here. These jagged peaks rise precipitously above the west prong of Little Little Pigeon River and the Newfound Gap Highway. For about five miles along this spectacular motor road the motorist is looking up to these peaks. Then, just before reaching the Tennessee-North Carolina state line at Newfound Gap, he may look down upon them. There is no graded trail or road up to the Chimney Tops, this being one of the peaks left for the enjoyment of the increasing numbers of hikers who like to "rough it."

titleInfo.title: Dome Falls on Roaring Fork Creek

mods.abstract: There are hundreds of waterfalls throughout the Great Smokies, and this one, found on the untrailed Roaring Fork Creek, is considered by some as the most beautiful of them all. The stream in this drop of some 75 feet comes to rest over a large round rock and this rock gives the impression of a great dome. It is from this great quarter round rock that this cascades gets its name.

mods.abstract: At Newfound Gap, in the center of the Great Smokies, was erected this rustic memorial commemorating the $5,000,000 gift from the Laura Spelman Rockefeller Foundation. This gift paid half the purchase price for this new national park of 440,000 acres. The memorial is on the Tennessee -- North Carolina state line, 55 miles from Knoxville. Mt. Le Conte, on the Tennessee side of the park, is seen in the background.

titleInfo.title: Rich Mt. Road into Cades Cove

mods.abstract: From the Knoxville-Cade's Cove highway we see this outstanding beauty spot of the Great Smokies. This is the only highway over Rich and Cove Mountains leading into picturesque Cade's Cove, shown in the center of the picture. The Cove, which is about six miles long and two miles wide, is completely surrounded by mountains. The high range in the backgorund forms the Tennessee-North Carolina state line. Thunderhead, the peak at the left, has an elevation of 5530 feet, while the cove is only 1807 feet above sea level.

mods.abstract: The ruggedness of Chimney Tops can not be appreciated until one climbs to the top. Here we see the craggy edges of one Chimney and, looking down the Little Pigeon River, we see the highway winding its way through the valley. Flowering shrubs grow from every crevice, and during the flowering season when the Rhododendrons and Allegheny Myrtle are in bloom it is a gorgeous sight.

mods.abstract: This quaintly named point on the Appalachian Trail -- four miles northeast of Newfound Gap -- is the destination of many hiking trips in the Great Smokies. This jagged point is no more rugged than other near-by peaks along the Sawtooth section of the Great Smokies. Its extreme ruggedness, however, was exposed to view when that spot was swept by fire in 1925.

titleInfo.title: Col. David C. Chapman and Group on Summit of Mt. Chapman

mods.abstract: In the foreground is Col. David C. Chapman, dynamic leader in the movement that brought about establishment of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Others in the picture, from left to right, are Harvey B. Boome, Mrs. Charles W. Myers, Miss Mildred Query and Jas. E. Thompson, all members of the Great Smoky Mountains Conservation Association, of which Col. Chapman is President, and which organization started the movement for the Park's establishment. Col. Chapman is one of very few living men to have a major mountain peak named for him. It is still more unusual for the honoree to climb the peak after it was named for him.

mods.abstract: On the way to Cades Cove you cross over the Little River near "Sunshine" Kinzel Springs. The Smokies can be seen in the distance. The head waters are in the park, beginning under Clingmans Dome, and are met at "The Forks" by the middle and west prong and flow into the Tennessee near Topside.

mods.abstract: One of the prettiest displays of water in the Great Smokies is at Laurel Falls. Here the word Falls is used in the plural advisedly, for there are really two separate and distinct falls -- one immediately above and the other immediately below the trail. In other words, the trail crosses the beautiful stream on a fifteen foot shelf that separates the two falls. In this view we see only the upper falls. The lower unit is equally interesting, and just as large. This beauty spot is only 1.3 miles from the paved Scenic Loop Highway at Fighting Creek Gap. Along the trail there are many fine views and a number of impressive rock cliffs.

mods.abstract: Arch Rock presents quite an unusual and spectacular formation. It looks as though this rock had toppled off from above and landed nearly up-side down in the Cavern below. The Alum Cave trail to Le Conte passes through the opening under the rock. The stream we see in the foreground is the Styx Branch. This name was given this branch as the stream originates in the section of the mountains known as Huggins Hell.

mods.abstract: While the top of the bald is grass clad, the edges of Gregory supports the finest known native stands of the exquisite flame azaleas. The colors range from a pure white, through the yellows, to a deep scarlet. These mountain-top meadows are not a result of "timber line", since higher peaks nearby are tree clad to their very tip tops. Scientists are not ageed on the cause of these balds, but all agree that they are not caused by timber lines. Many people fear that, since grazing has been stoppped, the balds may grow up in briars then revert to forest. This photograph is hand tinted.

mods.abstract: From Parsons Bald, near the southwestern end of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park, one can see the grassy dome of Gergory Bald (in the left background) and Rye Patch, on Long Hungry Ridge (the grassy open space in the right background). These balds are quite common on high peaks and ridges in the southwestern half of the park. Many people have assumes that they are "above timberline". This is not the case, however, as the size of the trees at the edge of the bald indicates. The phenomenon is explained as being the result of grazing over long periods -- first by deer, and later by domestic animals. These grassy balds were highly prized grazing lands for many years before the area became a national park.

mods.abstract: From the Greenbrier Pinnacle we get this wonderful view of Mt. Guyot and Mt. Chapman, two of the higher peaks on the Tennessee-North Carolina State line. Mt. Guyot, elevation 6621 feet, is the second highest peak in the Smokies and because of the dense stand of balsam and spruce which cover its summit, the only view to be had is from the top of the tower which was built about 1926 by the U.S. Geological Survey. Mt. Chapman, elevation 6430, feet is the fourth highest peak in the Park and was named for Col. David C. Chapman of Knoxville who led the long and difficult fight that brought about the establishment of the Park.

mods.abstract: About half way up the south side of Mt. Le Conte is a huge over-hanging cliff, which has long been known as Alum Cave. During the Civil war, salt-peter was mined, on a small scale, under the bluff, and the natives confused this salt-peter with alum, thence the name "Alum Cave". This is a favorite destination for naturalist and is extremely interesting to park visitors.

mods.abstract: Perhaps the most dramatic or spectacular spot in the Great Smokies is Charlies Bunion. It is on the Main crest of the Smokies, four miles northeast of Newfound Gap, and is reached only by the Appalachian Trail. This jagged point is no more rugged than other near-by peaks along the Sawtooth section of the Great Smokies. Its extreme ruggedness, however, was exposed to view when that spot was swept by fire in 1925. Dense forests give an apparent smoothness to equally precipitious points near this picturesquely named feature. Mt. Le Conte is seen in the right background.

mods.abstract: Throughout the Great Smoky Mountains National Park there is a great variety and a luxuriance of ferns. These ferns, under the virgin hardwood trees, are typical of those found in the southwestern half of the park. Under the coniferous trees along the summits of the higher peaks in the northeastern end of the Great smokies are the species that thrive in the deeper shade, with correspondingly more moisture.

mods.abstract: A writer who saw this picture recently referred to the Rhododendrons seen in it as "a barrier of beauty". Another, who had more experience in hiking or crawling through such tangled growths, added that it would be a barrier to anyone, regardless of personal pulchritude. To follow bear paths is almost the only way that hikers can penetrate Rhododendron thickets. This is the same growth that is, when seen from a distance, often called "Laurel slicks".

mods.abstract: Perhaps the most dramatic or spectacular spot in the Great Smokies is Charlies Bunion. It is on the Main crest of the Smokies, four miles northeast of Newfound Gap, and is reached only by the Applachian Trail. This jagged point is no more rugged that other near-by peaks along the Sawtooth section of the Great Smokies. Its extreme ruggedness, however, was exposed to view when that spot was swept by fire in 1925. Dense forests give an apparent smoothness to equally precipitious points near this pinturesquely named feature. Mt. Le Conte is seen in the right background.

mods.abstract: One of the most pleasing and picturesque spots in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park is the mountain bordered level section known as Cades Cove, situated at the western end of the Tennessee side of the park. The cove is about six miles long and from two to four miles wide, and is completely surrounded by high mountains, those in the background are called "The Great Smoky Range" and form the Tennessee-North Carolina State line. The only outlet is the circuitous route of Abrams Creek, the Stream which drains the cove and its surrounding wall of mountains. For many years the road seen here in the foreground was the only passable inlet for vehicles. The National Park Service has already built a second motor road, and plans another.

mods.abstract: In these mountains are found the world's greatest variety of trees, flowering shrubs and wild flowers. The Great Smokies geologically are among the oldest mountains in the world. In the center of this picture is the Greenbriar Cove and was generally referred to as the "Briar." And while the natives have now moved away we still find some of the old log cabins and occasionally an old rail fence as shown in the foreground of this picture

mods.abstract: There is a picturesque quality to these typical mountain homes throughout the foothills of the Great Smoky Mountains. The swinging bridge, seen here, is the generally used method for foot travel in crossing the streams. Vehicles and domestic animals had to ford the streams or stay on the same side. Quite a number of cabins in the park are still occupied, -- the owners having exercised their privilege to retain a life-time lease when selling their land and homes to the park, - but the poorer types that have been vacated have been removed so the surroundings can soon become "natural" again. This cabin is between Pigeon Forge and Gatlinburg, near the highway.

mods.abstract: There is ample room for parking hundreds of cars at the parking space near the top of Clingmans Dome. At this point the altitude is 6311 and is the highest point in Eastern America that can be reached by modern highway. This view of Clingmans Dome was taken from Silers Bald. In the center background is Clingmans Dome, highest point in the Park, -- the parking space can be seen at the right, -- at the left further back is Mt. Collins and between these two mountains is Collins Gap where the Skyway passes through.

mods.abstract: Although it is only a mile-and-a-half from the Newfound Gap Highway to the jagged crest of the Chimney Tops, the hikers are always ready for a rest and a bite to eat after the steep climb. And, hiking, over an extremely rough primitive trail, is the only way to reach this point, from which the most thrilling views are to be had. At points along the summit the ridge is so narrow that many hikers are too frightened to stand erect without holding on to shrubs or other hikers.

mods.abstract: A mid-winter view of Mt. Le Conte, uprearing its snow-capped head above a matchless group of lesser mountains and keeping benevolent guard over the sheltered valley which slumbers in the shadow of the majestic monarch. These peaks which rise to an elevation of 6593 feet above sea level, and a mile higher than the little village of Gatlinburg at their base are only 38 miles from Knoxville. They are snow-capped only two or three months during the year.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

mods.abstract: There are few, if any, more thrilling climbs in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park than the short but extremely rough ascent of the Chimney Tops, seen here. These jagged peaks rise precipitously above the west prong of Little Little Pigeon River and the Newfound Gap Highway. For about five miles along this spectacular motor road the motorist is looking up to these peaks. Then, just before reaching the Tennessee-North Carolina state line at Newfound Gap, he may look down upon them. There is no graded trail or road up the Chimney Tops, this being one of the peaks left for the enjoyment of the increasing numbers of hikers who like to "rough it."

mods.abstract: About half way up the south side of Mt. Le Conte is a huge over-hanging cliff, which has long been known as Alum Cave. During the Civil war, salt peter was mined, on a small scale, under the bluff, and the natives confused this salt-peter with alum, thence the name "Alum Cave". This spectacular spot is on the foot trail from Newfound Gap highway to the top of Mt. Le Conte, and is about two and half miles from "Grassy Patch" where the cars should be parked when taking this hike. It is a favorite destination for naturalist and is extremely interesting to park visitors.

mods.abstract: From the Forney Ridge parking plaza on Clingmans Dome we almost look into space. Our altitude brings us on level with, and very often above, the clouds. Here, there are times when the view seems endless one moment and in another you are completely enveloped, unable to see but a few feet in front of you. In this picture, we are looking southeast into North Carolina.

titleInfo.title: Little Pigeon River, Newfound Gap Road

mods.abstract: From the summit of the Chimney Tops, the hiker gets a number of thrilling panaramic views. In this, looking downstream, we see the Sugarland Valley, through which winds the lower part of the Tennessee side of the Newfound Gap Highway and the west prong of Little Little Pigeon River. At the left is one of the many peaks along Sugarland Mountains. In the background is Cove Mountain, on the border of the park. In the extreme distance the Chilhowee Mountain can be seen.

titleInfo.title: Rugged Peaks in the Southern Appalachians

mods.abstract: Clingman's Dome, 6642 feet above sea level, as seen from Mt. LeConte, elevation 6593 feet. The "dome" is on the Tennessee-North Carolina state line, while LeConte is entirely in Tennessee, about five miles from the state line. These two majestic peaks, together with Mt. Guyot, also on the state line, form the corners of a triangle which contains the world's greatest variety of trees, flowering shrubs, and wild flowers, and which also contains America's largest remaining boundary of virgin hardwood forest

titleInfo.title: River View to Mt. Le Conte

mods.abstract: There are many interesting views of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park from the highways leading from Knoxville to the Park. Without leaving your car you get this glimpse of Mt. Le Conte from the Chapman Highway, about a mile south of Sevierville. Mt. Le Conte rises more than a mile higher than its immediate base reaching an elevation of 6593 feet. In the foreground of this picture is seen the west prong of Little Little Pigeon River and in these lowlands or "river bottoms" live many prosperous farmers.

Le Conte, the grandstand of the Smokies, is therefore Eastern America's "Tallest" mountain.

mods.abstract: This picture, made from Myrtle Point of Mt. Le Conte, is considered one of the most typical views of the Great Smokies. It shows the ruggedness, the forest-clad features and also shows the elements at play. When clouds hang low over the Smokies, with a low temperature, dazzling hoarfrost will almost always form on the trees and vegetation -- as seen here in the foreground.

mods.abstract: The calm beauty of Rainbow Falls, on Le Conte Creek and half way up the new trail on the north side of Mt. Le Conte, changes quickly after long or hard rains to a thrilling and awe-inspiring spectacle as the larger volume of water makes the plunge of eighty five feet. Many people, who do not have time (or inclination) to climb to the summit of Le Conte, hike to Rainbow Falls.

mods.abstract: Near the Alum Cave Bluff, on the southside of majestic Mt. Le Conte, is the thin, leaning ridge with jagged points known as Duck Hawk Peaks. Under the over-hanging left side of the spectacular point a pair of duck hawks -- a favorite falcon -- has nested for many years. It takes a venturesome hiker or bird lover to scale the steep face of these peaks. Through these narrow ridges are holes or "windows."

mods.abstract: One of the prettiest displays of water in the Great Smokies is at Laurel Falls. Here the word Falls is used in the plural advisedly, for there are really two separate falls -- one immediately above and the other immediately below the trail. The trail crosses the beautiful stream on a fifteen-foot shelf that separates the two falls. In this view we see the upper.

mods.abstract: During the coldest weather, Rainbow Falls, halfway up the north side of Mt. Le Conte, presents a beautiful sight. The ice soon takes on the appearance of hugh white stalactite and stalagmite, but the weather has not remained cold long enough to bring them together. In fact there is little or no ice here during most of the winter. These falls have a drop of a eighty five feet.

titleInfo.title: Le Conte Lodge, Jack Huff Cabin

mods.abstract: Le Conte Lodge, on Mt. Le Conte, is a haven for thousands of hikers. The fragrant balsam bough beds and the cheerful wood fire are always popular, winter and summer after the hard climb of four miles to the top of Le Conte.
mods.note: To use photographs or to order reproductions which belong to the McClung Historical Collection, contact DigitalCollections@knoxlib.org or phone 865 215-8814. Please share the following identifier (ThGSM 226) and provide a brief description of the photograph.
See metadata for corresponding image in the McClung Historical Collection here: http://cmdc.knoxlib.org/cdm/singleitem/collection/p15136coll2/id/105/rec/1

mods.abstract: Unmatched varieties of wild flowers constitute the greatest attractions of the Great Smokies. In this picture we see the Catawbiense (purple) Rhododendrons bordering the Alum Cave Trail to Le Conte. This trail is one of the most attractive in the park, for if you hike only a short distance or the full length to the top there are points of interest all along the way. This view shows a close-up of what the mountaineers call "slicks" when in full bloom. These "slicks" appear quite smooth from a distance but unless a trail has been cut through them the hiker will find it very difficult to navigate and anything but smooth going.

titleInfo.title: Tulip Poplar and Hemlock, West Prong Pigeon River

mods.abstract: Along the streams in the Great Smokies--as here along the west prong of Little Pigeon River--are many beautiful groves of hemlock trees. Growing in a surrounding of deciduous or hardwood trees, the dark green of the hemlocks do much to enliven the winter landscapes. They also add a note of variety at other seasons, and particularly in the autumn when the other trees are vieing one with another for a gaudy display of colors.

mods.abstract: Throughout the coves and deep-cut gorges of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park are many stately tulip trees of large dimensions. It is not uncommon to find these trees, often called poplars, or yellow poplars by lumberman, that are six and seven feet in diameter and are 100 or more feet to the first limb. In comparison with the giant redwoods or sequoias of the west coast these are insignificant, they are quite large in comparison with other trees of the eastern part of the country.
